examples.comment: This date is special to the author, but it has no particular significance in date handling code.
This date is special to the author, but it has no particular significance in date handling code.
In most years there is no February 29th but this year there was.
The last day of February in a common year (year which is not a leap year).
The day following 28th February in a common year (year which is not a leap year).
The date of (Western) Good Friday varies every year. In many countries it is a holiday. Orthodox churches use a different date.
U.S. Thanksgiving is celebrated the fourth Thursday in November, and is a public holiday there.
The first working day following this days falls in the next month, and therefore Modified Following for this date is the previous day.

examples.description: One year before a leap day
examples.comment: This date could be calculated as the date one year before 29th Feb 1980.

examples.description: Also one year before a leap day
examples.comment: This date could be calculated as the date one year before 29th Feb 1980.

valid.description: A leap day in the year 2000
valid.comment: The year 2000 was a leap year.
This day was skipped in England when switching to the Gregorian calendar. It exists in the proleptic Gregorian calendar.
This day was skipped in France when switching to the Gregorian calendar. It exists in the proleptic Gregorian calendar.
This day was skipped in Sweden when switching to the Gregorian calendar. It exists in the proleptic Gregorian calendar.
The Unix epoch starts on the first day of 1970.

valid.description: First day of the Unix epoch
valid.comment: Unix timestamps count from this day, originally in seconds in a 32-bit integer.
Unix counts seconds from 1 Jan 1970. A 32-bit integer will overflow on this day.
AmigaOS counts seconds from 1 Jan 1978. A 32-bit integer will overflow on this day.

extra.comment: Not supported by some date libraries but a valid date nonetheless.
Not supported by some date libraries but a valid date nonetheless.

invalid.description: A leap day which did not exist
invalid.comment: INVALID: The year 1900 was not a leap year, but would have been in the Julian calendar. Some date libraries have historically got this wrong.

invalid.description: A day in a year which did not exist
A day which existed in the Swedish historical calendar
invalid.comment: INVALID: The Swedish calendar included Feb 30 in 1712, but the standard Gregorian calendar does not. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_non-standard_dates#February_30
